The effects of the [[Vietnam War]] tended to diminish the appetite for fictional war films by the turn of the 1970s. American war films produced during and just after the Vietnam War often reflected the disillusion of the American public towards the war. Most films made after the Vietnam War delved more deeply into the horrors of war than movies made before it (This is not to say that there were no such films before the Vietnam War). Later war films like ''[[Catch-22 (film)|Catch-22]]'' (set in WWII) and the [[black comedy]] ''[[MASH (film)|MASH]]'' (set in Korea), reflected some of these attitudes.
